t: Now I am old, whilst thou, by the mercy of heaven, art of a good age: take thou my place and my brother's, and go forth, and fight for our nation, and the help from Heaven be with you.
Then chose he out of the country twenty thousand men of war and horsemen, which went out toward Kendebeus, and lodged that night at Modin.
And when as they rose early in the morning, behold, an exceeding great host came to meet them, both footmen and horsemen: howbeit there was a brook betwixt them.
So he and his people pitched over against them: and when he saw that the people were afraid to go over the brook, he went first over himself, and then the other passed over after him.
Then divided he the horsemen into the midst of the footmen: for the enemies' horsemen were exceeding many.
And when they sounded with the trumpets, Kendebeus and his host were put to flight, so that many of them were slain, and the remnant gat them to the stronghold.
At that time was Judas John's brother wounded; howbeit John still followed after them, until he came to Kedron, which Kendebeus had built.
So they fled even unto the towers in the fields of Azotus; wherefore he burnt it with fire: and there fell of them about two thousand men. Afterward he returned into the land of Judea in peace.
Moreover Ptolemeus the son of Abubus was appointed captain in the plain of Jericho, and he had abundance of silver and gold:
For he was the high priest's son in law.
Wherefore his heart was lifted up, neither did he subdue the country, but sought to make himself great, and purposed deceitfully to take Simon and his sons out of the way.

Now as Simon was visiting the cities that were in the country, and taking care for the good ordering of them, he went down to Jericho, he and Mattathias and Judas, his sons, in the hundred and seventy and seventh year, in the eleventh month, called Sabat:
Where the son of Abubus received them deceitfully into a little hold, called Docus, which he had built, and made them a great banquet: howbeit he had hid men there.

So when Simon and his sons had drunk largely, Ptolemee and his men rose up, and took their weapons, and came upon Simon into the banqueting place, and slew him, and his two sons, and certain of his servants.
In which doing he committed a great treachery, and recompensed evil for good.
Then Ptolemee wrote these things, and sent to the king, that he should send him an host to aid him, and that he would deliver him the country and cities.
He sent others also to Gazera to kill John: and unto the tribunes he sent letters to come unto him, that he might give them silver, and gold, and rewards.
And dispatched he forces unto Jerusalem, and to seize upon the mountain of the temple.
Now one had run afore to Gazera and told John that his father and brethren were slain, and, quoth he, Ptolemee hath sent to slay thee also.
When he heard this, he was sore astonished: then he sent and slew all the men that were come to destroy him, for he knew that they sought to make him away.
As concerning the rest of the acts of John, and his wars, and worthy deeds which he did, and the building of the walls which he made, and his doings,
Behold, these are written in the book of the chronicles of his priesthood, from the time he was made high priest after his father.
The brethren, the Jews that are at Jerusalem and in the land of Judea, wish unto the brethren, the Jews that are throughout Egypt health and peace:
God be gracious unto you, and remember his covenant that he made with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, his faithful servants.
And give you all an heart to serve him truly, to do his will with a good courage and a willing mind;
And open your hearts in his law and commandments, and send you peace,
And fulfil your petitions, and be merciful unto you, and forsake you not in time of trouble.
And now we be here praying for you.

When Demetrius reigned, in the hundred threescore and ninth year, we the Jews wrote unto you as follows: In the trouble and extremity that came upon us in those years, from the time that Jason and his company revolted from the holy land and kingdom,
And burned the gate, and shed innocent blood: then we prayed unto the Lord, and were heard; we offered also sacrifices and fine flour, and lighted the lamps, and set forth the loaves.
And now see that ye keep the feast of tabernacles in the month Casleu.

In the hundred fourscore and eighth year, the people that are at Jerusalem and in Judea, with the council, and Judas, unto Aristobulus, king Ptolemeus' master, who is of the stock of the anointed priests, and to the Jews that are in Egypt: send greeting and wish you all health.
Since we are delivered out of great perils, we thank God greatly, that he did help us against the king,
For he cast them out that fought within the holy city.
For when the leader was come into Persia, and the army with him that seemed invincible, they were slain in the temple of Nanea through the deceit of Nanea's priests.
For Antiochus, as though he would marry her, came into the place, and his friends that were with him, to receive money in the name of a dowry.
Which when Nanea's priests had set forth, and he was entered with a small company into the compass of the temple, they shut the temple as soon as Antiochus was come in:
Which done, they opened a privy door of the roof, and cast stones like thunderbolts, and struck down the captain, hewed them in pieces, smote off their heads and cast them to those that were without.
Blessed be our God in all things, who hath delivered the ungodly unto punishment.

Therefore whereas we are now purposed to keep the purification of the temple upon the five and twentieth day of the month Casleu, we thought it necessary to certify you thereof, that ye also might keep it, as the feast of the tabernacles, and of the fire, which was given us when Neemias offered sacrifice, after that he had builded the temple and the altar.

For when our fathers were led into Persia, the priests that were then devout took the fire of the altar privily, and hid it in an hollow place of a pit without water, where they kept it sure, so that the place was unknown to all men.

Now after many years, when it pleased God, Neemias being sent from the king of Persia did send of the posterity of those priests that had hid it to the fire: but when they told us they found no fire, but thick water;
Then commanded he them to draw it up, and to bring it; and when the sacrifices were laid on, Neemias commanded the priests to sprinkle the wood and the things laid thereupon with the water.
When this was done, and the time came that the sun shone, which afore was hid in the cloud, there was a great fire kindled, so that every man marvelled.
And the priests made a prayer, whilst the sacrifice was consuming, I say, both the priests, and all the rest, Jonathan beginning, and the rest answering thereunto, as Neemias did.
And the prayer was to this effect; O Lord, Lord God, Creator of all things, who art fearful and strong, and righteous, and merciful, and the only and gracious King,
The only giver of all things, the only just, almighty, and everlasting, thou that deliverest Israel from all trouble, and didst choose our fathers, and sanctify them:
Receive this sacrifice for all thy people Israel, and preserve their portion, and sanctify it.
Gather those together that are scattered from us, deliver them that serve among the heathen, look upon them that are despised and abhorred, and let the heathen know that thou art our God.
Punish them that oppress us, and deal proudly against us.
Plant thy people again in thy holy place, as Moses hath spoken.
And the priests sung psalms of thanksgiving.
Now when the sacrifice was consumed, Neemias commanded the rest of the water to be poured on the great stones.
Which when it was done, there was kindled a flame: but it was consumed by the light that shone from the altar.

So when this matter was known, it was told the king of Persia, that in the place, where the priests that were led away had hid the fire, there was water found, and that Neemias had purified the sacrifices therewith.
Then the king enclosed the place, and made it holy, after he had tried the matter.
And the king appointed certain revenues for the priests, which they took of him.
And Neemias called this thing Naphthar, which is as much as to say, a cleansing: but many men call it Nephi.
For it is found in the records, that Jeremy the prophet commanded them that were carried away to take of the fire, as it hath been signified:

And how that the prophet, having given them the law, charged them not to forget the commandments of the Lord, and that they should not err in their minds, when they see images of silver, and gold, with their ornaments.
And with other such speeches exhorted he them, that the law should not depart from their hearts.

It was also contained in the same writing, that the prophet, being warned of God, commanded the tabernacle and the ark to go with him, as he went forth into the mountain, where Moses climbed up, and saw the heritage of God.
And when Jeremy came thither, he found an hollow cave, wherein he laid the tabernacle, and the ark, and the altar of incense, and so stopped the door.
And some of those that followed him came to mark the way, but they could not find it.
Which when Jeremy perceived, he blamed them, saying, As for that place, it shall be unknown until the time that God gather his people again together, and receive them unto mercy.

Then shall the Lord shew them these things again, and the glory of the Lord shall appear, and the cloud also, as it was shewed under Moses, and as when Solomon desired that the place might be honourably sanctified.
It was also declared, that he being wise did offer the sacrifice of dedication, and of the finishing of the temple.
And as Moses prayed unto the Lord, and the fire came down from heaven, and consumed the sacrifices: even so prayed Solomon also, and the fire came down from heaven, and consumed the burnt offerings.
And Moses said, Because the sin offering was not to be eaten, it was consumed.
So Solomon kept those eight days.

The same things also were reported in the records and commentaries of Neemias; and how he founding a library gathered together the acts of the kings, and the prophets, and of David, and the letters of the kings concerning the holy gifts.
In like manner also Judas gathered together all those things that were lost by reason of the war we had, and they remain with us.
If therefore ye have need thereof, send some to fetch them unto you.
Whereas we then are about to celebrate the purification, we have written unto you, and ye shall do well, that ye keep the same days.
We hope also, that the God, that delivered all his people, and gave us all an heritage, and the kingdom, and the priesthood, and the sanctuary,

As he promised in the law, will shortly have mercy upon us, and gather us together out of every land under heaven into the holy place: for he hath delivered us out of great troubles, and hath purified the place.
Now as concerning Judas Maccabeus and his brethren, and the purification of the great temple, and the dedication of the altar,
And the wars against Antiochus Epiphanes, and Eupator his son,

And the manifest signs that came from heaven unto those that behaved themselves manfully to their honour for Judaism: so that, being but a few, they recovered the whole country, and chased barbarous multitudes,
And recovered again the temple renowned over all the world, and freed the city, and upheld the laws which were going down, the Lord being gracious unto them with all favour:
All these things having been set forth in five books by Jason of Cyrene, we shall attempt to epitomize them in a single work.
Considering the flood of figures and the difficulty that those who wish to enter into the intricacies of the narratives of history experience, because of the abundance of matter,
we have been mindful to offer delight to those who are content with a simple reading, convenience to those who like to entrust the facts to their memory, advantage to all indistinctly.
For us who have undertaken the arduous labor of this summary, it is not an easy task, but a matter of sweat and sleeplessness,
no less difficult than that of the arranger of a feast who seeks to procure the satisfaction of others. In the same way, to render service to many people, we shall bear this arduous labor agreeably,
leaving to the writer the care to be complete on each event in order to strive to follow the outlines of a simple precis.

For even as the architect of a new house must attend to the whole structure, while he who undertakes to decorate it with encaustic paintings must seek what is appropriate to the ornamentation, so, I think, it is for us.
To penetrate into the questions and go around them to examine with curiosity all the detail belongs to him who composes the history,
but, to him who makes an adaptation, it must be conceded that he seeks the conciseness of the exposition and renounces an exhaustive history.
Let us therefore begin here our relation without adding anything to what has been said, for it would be foolish to be diffuse before beginning the history and concise in the history itself.
While the holy city was inhabited in complete peace and the laws were observed as exactly as possible, because of the piety of the high priest Onias and his hatred for evil,
it happened that the kings themselves honored the holy place and enhanced the glory of the Temple by the most magnificent gifts,
so much so that Seleucus, king of Asia, covered with his personal revenues all the expenses necessary for the service of the sacrifices.
But a certain Simon, of the tribe of Bilga, appointed provost of the Temple, found himself in disagreement with the high priest over the policing of the city's markets.
As he could not prevail over Onias, he went to find Apollonius, son of Thraseas, who was at that time the strategos of Coele-Syria and Phoenicia.

He reported that the treasury of Jerusalem abounded with unspeakable riches to the point that the quantity of the sums was incalculable and not at all in relation to the account required by the sacrifices: it was possible to make them fall into the possession of the king.

In the course of an interview with the king, Apollonius informed him of the riches that had been denounced to him. Settling his choice on Heliodorus, who was at the head of affairs, the king sent him with order to proceed to the removal of the aforementioned riches.
Immediately Heliodorus set out, ostensibly to inspect the cities of Coele-Syria and Phoenicia, but in fact to accomplish the intentions of the king.
Arrived in Jerusalem, and received with kindness by the high priest and by the city, he shared what had been revealed and manifested the purpose of his presence, then asking if it was truly so.
The high priest represented to him that the treasury contained the deposits of widows and orphans.
